Though Reverend McKinney has passed away, his legacy and advocacy for equal rights of African-Americans will remain ever present in the Greater Seattle community. https://adamsmith.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/smith-statement-honoring-the-life-and-legacy-of-rev-dr-samuel-b-mckinney

He helped establish the first black-owned bank to challenge practices such as restricted loans. He also co-founded the Seattle Opportunities Industrialization Center, a vocational training organization.

When he arrived in Seattle, he witnessed systematic injustices such as discrimination, redlining, high unemployment among African-Americans. Reverend McKinney established numerous organizations and businesses to combat discrimination.

A former classmate of Dr. King's he played a fundamental role in Dr. King‚Äôs trip to Seattle. As spiritual leader for many in the African-American community in Seattle, Reverend McKinney understood that for African-Americans to be fully empowered they must be uplifted economically

With the passing of Rev. Dr. Samuel B. McKinney, our community has lost an instrumental leader of the civil rights movement.  After moving to Seattle in 1957 to become a pastor in the historic Mount Zion Baptist Church, Reverend McKinney was a pastor in the church for over 40 yrs

That's why I'm thrilled to help pass the Music Modernization Act out of our Judiciary Committee and why I look forward to supporting it on the House floor. üé∂

Music is so important to all of our lives and it allows for expression in a way that few other mediums do. My son is a musician and I've seen how songwriting, performing and creative collaboration have been a rock for him.

It's crucial we support this art and those who make it.

For artists everywhere, the Music Modernization Act will ensure they can earn a more just living, giving them freedom to focus on their art instead of just making ends meet.

This bill is supported by artists, publishers and broadcasters alike ‚Äì it's the right step forward.

Seattle is the birthplace of grunge and the home of legends like Kurt Cobain, Jimi Hendrix and @PearlJam. We have so many amazing artists in our region ‚Äì @dcfc, @BlueScholars, @wongweezy, and musicians who are building their followings and relying on fair, equitable payment.

Proud to have voted YES on this bill in Judiciary Committee today.

The Music Modernization Act means so much to musicians everywhere, but I'm especially proud to support this bill for our home city Seattle ‚Äì one of our nation's great musical beacons.
